description: The age of the customer may influence their likelihood to stay with the account, with older customers potentially being more loyal.
Customers with higher average monthly spend may be less likely to close their account due to the value they perceive from the services.
Customers who have frequent interactions with customer service may be more likely to churn due to dissatisfaction or unresolved issues.
Customers who have a longer history with the company may be less likely to churn compared to new customers.
Customers who actively use and benefit from a rewards program may be more likely to stay with the account.
Customers who use the services frequently may be less likely to churn compared to those who use them sparingly.
The availability of competitive offerings in the market may influence the customer's decision to stay or leave.
Analyzing the sentiment of customer feedback and reviews can provide insight into their likelihood to churn.
Major life events such as moving, getting married, or having children may impact a customer's decision to continue with their account.
External economic conditions such as recessions or economic booms may impact a customer's financial situation and thus their decision to keep or close their account.
